text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in the Swedish papers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Swedish female doctors are more prone to give antibiotics to patients than male doctors are, according to research done by the Swedish Karolinska Institute.
- Video footage of the Estonia ferry, which sank in 1994 killing over 800 people, is to be examined by experts to determine if the ferry sank because of inadequate maintenance.
- The annual conference of the Swedish Trade Union Confederation (LO) is estimated to cost 60,000 Swedish crowns per delegate.

- Four percent wage rises per year, an annual inflation rate of two percent, is the economic goal for 1998-2001 which Swedish Prime Minister Goran Persson will try to sell to members of the Swedish Trade Union Confederation (LO) on Wednesday.
- Despite widespread criticism of the Social Democratic government's reforms, the Swedish Trade Union Confederation (LO) will not break its alliance with the government.

- Carnegie, the Swedish brokerage house, is to have lent 140 million Swedish crowns to a Canadian company, Xavier Mines, through suspended Morgan Grenfell fund manager Peter Young, who is currently under investigation for mismanagement.

- The Swedish Trade Union Confederation (LO) owns shares on the Stockholm bourse worth 5.3 billion Swedish crowns, mostly invested in construction and real estate companies, according to a survey by Dagens Industri.
